greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Triangle read by rows: T(n, k) is the number of divisors of n that are less than or equal to k for 1 <= k <= n.
comment: This triangular sequence T(n,k) generalizes sequence A000005, the number of divisors of n; in particular, A000005(n) = T(n,n).
Also, for prime p, T(p,k) = 1 when k < p and T(p,p) = 2.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Rows n = 1..125 of triangle, flattened
Dennis P. Walsh, Notes on counting the divisors of n
formula: T(n,k) = coefficient of the x^n term in the expansion of Sum(x^j/(1-x^j), j=1..k).
example: T(6,4)=3 since there are 3 divisors of 6 that are less than or equal to 4, namely, 1, 2 and 3.
maple: for n from 1 to 19 do seq(T(n, k), k = 1..n) od; # _Peter Luschny_, Jan 02 2021
program: (PARI) T(n, k) = sumdiv(n, d, d<=k); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Jun 17 2014
xref: Cf. A000005 (diagonal), A000012 (first column), A081307 (row sums), A027750 (divisors of n).
results.author: _Dennis P. Walsh_, Jun 16 2014
